title: Echo takes science to new heights with new theater
text:
Echo takes science to new heights with new theater Two National Geographic films on display UPDATED 10:51 AM EDT Oct 10, 2015 
Echo Lake Aquarium and Science Center is unveiling a new theater that will showcase National Geographic documentations featuring airplanes and sea monsters. Related 
Click here to watch the story. 
“It's an immersive film experience that you can only get in a museum,” said Steve Perkins, of Echo. 
Starting Oct. 10, the new Northfield Savings Bank theater will loop two National Geographic movies each day: "Living in the Age of Airplanes" and "Sea Monsters: A Prehistoric Adventure." 
The films run about 45 minutes, and ‘Sea Monsters’ is in 3D. 
“We have partnered with National Geographic, which everyone knows makes a great magazine and great films, to bring their museum-specific films here to Echo,” said Perkins. 
While the new, state of the art theater is a permanent fixture, the films will change every three months, giving visitors a variety they wouldn't ordinarily find at echo. 
“You know, it takes a long time to change an exhibit, so we don't change our exhibits every three months,” said Perkins. 
But other changes are coming to the science center. Just across from the theater, Echo is in the middle of building its new preschool play space, which is expected to be finished early 2016. 
Thanks to a grant from Google, what may look like a bunch of colorful light bulbs now, will be a first of its kind 3-D LED light display that's scheduled to be up and running by December. 
For more information on times and pricing for the National Geographic Experience, click here. Tags WPTZ Vermont Burlinton Echo Science National Geographic Jarred Hill
